I. Introduction
A. Purpose of the Study
This paper aims to analyze and compare three science fiction novels: "Rossum's Universal Robots" (1920) by Karel Čapek, "Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?" (1968) by Philip K. Dick, and "Neuromancer" (1984) by William Gibson. Through the lens of psychoanalytic criticism, the paper will explore the unconscious motivations, desires, and conflicts revealed in the forms, details, and language of the novels.

B. Overview of the Novels
"Rossum's Universal Robots" is a Czech play that introduced the term "robot" and popularized the genre of science fiction. The play revolves around the idea of artificial intelligence and its impact on humanity.
"Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?" is a novel set in a post-apocalyptic world where robots, known as androids, have become an integral part of society. The protagonist, a bounty hunter, must distinguish between androids and humans in order to complete his missions.
"Neuromancer" is a novel that explores the concept of virtual reality and the relationship between technology, consciousness, and identity. The protagonist is a washed-up computer hacker who is recruited for one last job in the virtual world known as the "Matrix."

C. Methodology
The methodology of this paper will consist of a close reading of the texts, informed by the theories of Sigmund Freud and psychoanalytic criticism. The analysis will focus on the psychological implications of the forms and details of the novels, including the characters, themes, symbols, and language. The paper will also consider the author's intention and the context in which the novels were written. In addition, relevant information from the Saved as Paper articles #1 to #9 will be quoted and cited to provide a more complete understanding of the works.

II. "Rossum's Universal Robots" by Karel Capek
A. Background Information
In "Rossum's Universal Robots," Karel Capek explores the idea of artificial intelligence and the consequences of creating machines with human-like qualities. This novel, published in 1920, predates many of the advancements in technology that we have today and serves as a cautionary tale about the dangers of creating machines that are too similar to humans.

B. Analysis through the Lens of Psychoanalysis

1. The Unconscious and the Collective Unconscious
Through the creation of robots, Capek highlights the concept of the unconscious and the collective unconscious. The robots in the novel are programmed to follow orders, but their actions are not motivated by conscious thought. Instead, their behavior is driven by their programming, which can be seen as a representation of the unconscious.

II. "Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?" by Philip K. Dick
A. Background Information
Philip K. Dick's "Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?" was first published in 1968 and is a science fiction novel set in a post-apocalyptic world. The novel explores the nature of humanity and the question of what it means to be human. It is a story about a group of androids who are trying to escape from their creators and find a place in a world that is dominated by humans.

B. Analysis through the Lens of Psychoanalysis

1. The Human Condition
One of the central themes of the novel is the human condition and the ways in which people cope with the challenges of life. As the androids struggle to find their place in the world, they are faced with the question of what it means to be human. According to the paper "Saved as Paper #7: The Human Condition in Philip K. Dick's 'Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?'" the novel asks "the question of what makes us human, what is the defining characteristic that sets us apart from machines and robots." The androids in the novel must grapple with their own identity and question whether they are capable of experiencing human emotions and sensations.
2. The Concept of Reality
Another central theme of the novel is the concept of reality and the ways in which people perceive and experience the world around them. According to the paper "Saved as Paper #2: The Concept of Reality in Philip K. Dick's 'Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?'" the novel explores "the idea that reality is subjective and that our perception of the world is shaped by our own experiences and beliefs." This is seen in the way that the androids in the novel question their own experiences and try to understand the world around them.
3. The Notion of the Self
The concept of self is also explored in the novel, as the androids struggle to understand who they are and their place in the world. According to the paper "Saved as Paper #9: The Notion of the Self in Philip K. Dick's 'Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?'" the novel asks "questions about the nature of the self, what it means to be an individual, and what it means to have a unique identity." The androids in the novel must come to terms with their own individuality and their place in the world, as they try to find a place in a world that is dominated by humans.

IV. "Neuromancer" by William Gibson
A. Background Information
"Neuromancer" is a science fiction novel written by William Gibson and published in 1984. It is considered a seminal work in the cyberpunk genre, and is often cited as one of the most influential science fiction novels of all time. The novel is set in a dystopian future, where the protagonist, Case, is a washed-up computer hacker who is hired by a mysterious employer to pull off a dangerous hack.

B. Analysis through the Lens of Psychoanalysis

1. The Concept of Humanity
In "Neuromancer," Gibson explores the concept of humanity through the character of Case, who struggles with the meaning of his own existence. The novel raises questions about what it means to be human, as the distinction between human and machine becomes increasingly blurred. According to a Saved as Paper article #5, "Gibson uses the character of Case to question what it means to be human in a world where technology has advanced to the point where the distinction between man and machine is becoming increasingly blurred."
2. The Concept of Reality
In the novel, Gibson also explores the concept of reality, as Case navigates a virtual world that is indistinguishable from the real world. The line between what is real and what is virtual is blurred, and the reader is left to question the nature of reality itself. As Saved as Paper article #7 states, "Gibson's depiction of the virtual world in 'Neuromancer' raises questions about the nature of reality, as the line between what is real and what is virtual becomes increasingly blurred."
3. The Notion of the Self
Finally, "Neuromancer" also explores the notion of the self, as Case grapples with his own identity and purpose. The novel raises questions about the nature of the self, and the extent to which it is shaped by technology and the virtual world. According to Saved as Paper article #9, "Gibson's portrayal of Case's journey in 'Neuromancer' raises questions about the nature of the self, and the extent to which it is shaped by technology and the virtual world."
